items.name: Equipment
items.entry: A ceremonial circlet or diadem (A mark of your ascension to Amazon), a set of {@item common clothes|phb}, and a belt pouch containing 15gp

entries.name: Restriction: Female Only
entries: Only women can become Amazons, men are exiled or slaughtered once they have fulfilled their purpose.

entries.name: Feature: Amazon Pride
entries: Amazons are well revered warriors. Whether you are loved or feared, you find that people are often willing to be more lenient with prices and services.
Provided you are still welcome with the Amazons, you can expect free lodging and food for you and your companions within Amazon camps, so long as the men don't stay too long.

entries.name: Reason For Leaving
entries: You have been separated from your tribe for some reason. You can roll on the table to determine why, or chose one that best fits your character.

rows: I was sent on a special mission by my queen, one only I could complete.
I was captured and later escaped, I am trying to find my tribe again.
I was shunned and exiled for refusing to kill/leave my mate/son.
The tribe brings back painful memories, I had to leave.
I am searching for artefacts and allies to help my tribe.
I disagreed with the tribe and decided to go my own way.
I am the only surviving member of my tribe, I am searching for other Amazon tribes.
I simply wanted to explore the world.
I speak down to all men as if they are animals.
I only know war and wilderness, social etiquette and commerce are alien to me.
I am constantly looking for a fight to prove myself to strangers.
The sight of people living ordinary lives amuses me for some reason.
I am always ready for battle, I don't have time for bathing or looking nice.
I don't like subterfuge, I will not lie and hate when others lie.
The simplest, most direct method is usually the best.
I like to scare companions with stories from my life with the tribe.
I only value strength, I care not for morals or wisdom. (Evil)
I must follow the customs and laws of my tribe, even if I don't like it. (Lawful)
I must use what strength I have to serve the greater good. (Good)
I refuse to follow orders I disapprove of. (Chaotic)
An honourable enemy can always become a good friend. (Neutral)
Ambition, I will be more than just another woman, I will be legendary. (Any)
I serve my queen, I have no other loyalties.
I will serve Ares to my dying breath.
My honour is my life.
No man shall ever rule me.
My tribe is wrong about men, I shall never shun/execute an innocent man.
I fight for those who cannot fight for themselves.
I have little respect for anyone who is not a proven warrior.
To surrender in battle is the greatest shame I can feel.
I made a terrible mistake in battle that cost many lives-and I would do anything to keep that mistake secret.
My hatred of my enemies is blinding and unreasoning.
I obey my queen, even when I disagree with the order.
I refuse to follow the laws of the lands beyond my tribe, this constantly gets me in trouble.

entries: You hail from a famous tribe of warrior women known as the Amazons. Amazons pride themselves on their strength and independence. Men are not permitted among their ranks and are only used for breeding.

Some tribes have agreements with neighbouring tribes and settlements in which, once a year the strongest men are chosen to mate with the Amazons. Any girls born from this union are raised as Amazons themselves while the boys are sent back to their fathers.
In more aggressive tribes, men are captured during raids, enslaved and then slaughtered after the deed is done. Any boys resulting from these unions are usually killed or abandoned.

items.name: Languages
items.entry: One exotic language of your choice (agreed with the DM).

items.name: Equipment
items.entry: A bottle of black ink, a quill, a small knife, a ring or amulet signifying your membership in the Magi of Hecate, a set of {@item fine clothes|phb}, and a belt pouch containing 10gp.

entries.name: Feature: Magi Membership
entries: If you are still welcome with the Magi, you can rely on certain benefits that membership provides. You can meet up with colleagues in most settlements larger than a village. These colleagues can help you find information, jobs and make connections to potential allies and patrons. You can usually find enough odd jobs to fund a modest lifestyle with the Magi's help.
You may also earn small discounts when procuring services from other magi, such as performing certain spells, buying and crafting magic items or hiring tutors and mercenaries.

You must pay dues of 5 gp per month to the Magi of Hecate. If you miss payments, you must make up back dues to remain in the Magi's good graces. If you miss too many payments, you may be expelled and need to earn your way back in to regain the benefits of membership.

entries.name: Magus Specialism
entries: Some magi have specialist roles and tend towards jobs aligning with their specialisms. You can select your specialism from the table below or roll randomly, you may also come up with your own.

rows: Generalist.
No specialism.
Utilitarian.
Repairing tools and furniture and performing basic tasks for people.
Entertainer.
Performing party tricks, conjuring wine and fireworks.
Alchemist.
Making and identifying potions and poisons.
Archivist.
Collecting, trading and studying magic items and records.
Healer.
Mending wounds, curing diseases and breaking curses.
Enchanter.
Creating magic items, glyphs and wards.
Tutor.
Training mages, from beginners to experts.
Mercenary.
Fighting, supporting expeditions or training magically-enhanced troops.
Zoologist.
Study of magic creatures and extra-planar beings.
Researcher.
Experimenting and studying new spells and magic.
Advisor.
Advisor to political, religious and military leaders, particularly on subjects related to magic.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Generally, most magi have experience with magic and are accomplished spellcasters, though this is not technically a requirement, the study of magic or magic items is usually enough to grant you membership. Despite their official devotion to Hecate, the magi tend to be more academic or vocational than religious.

rows: I always listen deeply and think carefully before speaking.
I am often insulted by the petty requests common people make of magi, they are a waste of my talents.
I find my work or study far more interesting than dealing with people.
I quote (or misquote) sacred texts and proverbs in almost every situation.
I add a magical flair to almost everything I do, even simple activities like eating a meal or opening a book.
I am always trying to talk people into hiring my services, even when they don't need them.
I don't part with my money easily and will haggle tirelessly to get the best deal possible.
I look down upon those who don't (or can't) use magic.
Generosity. My talents were given to me so that I could use them to benefit the world. (Good)
Law. Magic should be used to enforce the laws of both gods and mortals. (Lawful)
Knowledge. Improving personal and public knowledge should always be a goal, no matter who uses it. (Neutral)
Change. Magic is a tool with which anyone can change the world. (Chaotic)
Gain. I joined the magi solely to seek power, influence or wealth, that desire still drives me above all others. (Evil)
Aspiration. I seek to prove myself a worthy magus to the world and to Hecate herself. (Any)
I adore some or all of my colleagues and will do whatever I can to help them.
Protecting, and providing for, my clients or students is my highest priority.
My workshop or study is one place I feel truly safe and comfortable.
Everything I do, I do to impress a specific person.
My life's work is pursuing or protecting the answer to some great mystery.
I have a rival magus, I will do all I can to be better than them.
My curiosity regarding unknown magics can often lead me into danger.
I'm quick to assume that someone is trying to cheat me.
I always expect to be treated like nobility, even where I have no such authority or status.
I frequently overwork myself at the cost of sleeping or eating properly.
I am never wrong, even when I am.
I fear that I am a fraud and can never live up to the praise and expectations placed upon me.

entries: You are, or were, a member of the much exalted Magi of Hecate, a group of acolytes and academics studying magic and magic items as well as providing magical services, for a fee. Many magi may try to distance themselves from their reputation as mages-for-hire or mercenaries but even magi need money.

It is common for groups of magi to covene in and around temples, shrines and academic institutions to exchange services, knowledge and to collaborate in arcane research and work. Magi can be found in such places in most cities and large towns.

deity.name: Chaos
deity.title: The Original Entity
entries: Chaos was the first entity to exist, they are older than the cosmos itself. To worship Chaos is to worship absence and nothingness. Chaos does not grant any boons or rewards for worship.

customProperties.Typical Forms: Aasimar, Currently Incorporeal in the pit of Tartarus
Triton, Water Elemental, Merman, Giant Crab

deity.name: Prometheus
deity.title: Father of Humans
deity.province: Creator of Humans, Dwarves, Elves and Orcs

customProperties.Typical Forms: Elf, Aasimar, Manifestation of viewer's desires

deity.name: Apollo
deity.title: Lord of Music
deity.province: Music, Lyre, Poetry, Archery, The Sun, Prophecies and Oracles

customProperties.Worshipers: Bards, Poets, Oracles, Fortune Tellers, Archers, Temples

deity.name: Athena
deity.title: Lady of Wisdom
deity.province: Wisdom, Martial Strategy, Politics and Elves

customProperties.Worshipers: Warriors, Amazons, Generals, Politicians, Scholars, Elves
Performers, Whore, Hedonists, Innkeepers, Vineyards, Temples
Smiths, Tinkers, Firewielders, Dwarves, Warforged, Temples

deity.name: Hera
deity.title: Lady of Marriage
deity.province: Women, Marriage, Family, Punishing Adulterers and Bigamists

deity.name: Hermes
deity.title: Lord of Messengers
deity.province: Thieves, Messengers, Travellers, Shepherds, Medicine, Psychopomp for Great Heroes

customProperties.Worshipers: Thieves, Messengers, Travellers, Shepherds, Physicians, Temples

deity.name: Zeus
deity.title: Lord of the Sky
deity.province: King of Olympians, The Sky, Lighting, Xenia, Kings

customProperties.Worshipers: Undertakers, Graveyard Keepers, Necromancers, Temples, Cultists, Assassins
Mages, Scholars of Magic, Some Temples

deity.name: Thanatos
deity.title: The Soul Guide
deity.province: Personification of Death, Psychopomp for dead souls

feat.name: Oceanid Warrior
entries: You learn the fighting style of the Oceanids. You gain the following benefits:

items: When you wield a {@item trident|phb} or {@item bident|cyranos}, its damage die changes from a {@dice d6} to a {@dice d8} when wielded in one hand, and from a {@dice d8} to a {@dice d10} when wielded with two hands. (This benefit has no effect if another feature has already improved the weapon's die.)
When you make a melee attack with a {@item trident|phb} or {@item bident|cyranos} against a creature while either of you are underwater, you gain advantage on the attack roll.
Your reach with {@item trident|phb|tridents} or {@item bident|cyranos|bidents} with which you are proficient is increased by 5 feet.

item.name: Satyr's Wine
entries: This sweet wine is made by satyrs from forest fruits grown by dryads. When you drink this wine, you must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, you become {@condition charmed} by all creatures that you can see of any species and gender you are normally attracted to. You can repeat the saving throw at the end of every hour until you succeed and are no longer {@condition charmed}.

item.name: Hourglass of Kronos
entries: This finely crafted hourglass holds one minute of sand and bears an engraving of a scythe on one side.
The hourglass has 2 charges and regains {@dice 1d3-1} charges daily at dawn.

While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 or more of its charges to cast the {@spell time stasis|J:General} spell (save DC 12) from it. For 1 charge, you cast the 4th-level version of the spell. You can increase the spell slot level by one for each additional charge you expend.

item.name: Orb of Helios and Selene
entries: This tiny glass orb sheds dim light in a 5-foot radius and shows an image of the sun, during the day, or the moon, during the night.
While holding this orb, you can use an action to read the image and determine whether it is morning, afternoon, evening, or nighttime outside. This property functions only on the Material Plane.

item.name: Sandals of the Styx
entries: These sandals have supposedly been dipped in the river styx at the border of the underworld and thus grant the wearer the powers of Achilles.
While wearing these sandals all non-magical weapon attacks against you have disadvantage.

entries.name: Curse
entries: These sandals are cursed. Attuning to them curses you until you are targeted by a spell such as {@spell remove curse} or a similar effect. While cursed, your attunement to the object cannot be broken, and any successful weapon attacks against you are treated as critical hits.

item.name: Bellerophon's Horn
entries: Once attuned to the horn you can blow it to summon a {@creature pegasus|mm}.
The pegasus is friendly to you and your companions. It understands your languages and obeys your spoken commands. If you issue no commands, the pegasus defends itself but takes no other actions.

When the pegasus drops to 0 hit points, it disappears in a cloud of mist, leaving behind no physical form, and cannot be summoned again until dawn the next dawn. You can also dismiss the pegasus at any time as an action, causing it to disappear in the same way.

item.name: Sandals of Atalanta
entries: While you are attuned to and wearing these sandals your walking speed increases by 10ft.

item.name: Wings of Daedalus
entries: While you are attuned to and wearing these wings you gain a flying speed of 30ft.

These wings require both arms to operate and so you cannot use your arms or hands whilst flying or hovering. Whilst on the ground, you can remove your arms from the contraption and use them normally while the wings hang uselessly off your back.

item.name: Helm of Darkness
entries: The helm has 3 charges and regains {@dice 1d4-1} charges daily at dawn.
As an action, you can expend one charge to cast {@spell greater invisibility|phb} on yourself.

item.name: Nemean Lion Pelt
entries: While wearing this pelt, you have resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.
This pelt cannot be worn over medium or heavy armor.

item.name: Spear of Kelphalos
entries: This weapon has 3 charges and regains {@dice 1d4-1} charges daily at dawn. When you miss a ranged attack with this weapon you can expend one charge to hit instead, this hit cannot be a critical hit.

item.name: Hippolyta's Girdle
entries: While wearing this belt, your Strength score changes to 21. The item has no effect on you if your Strength without the belt is equal to or greater than the belt's score.
This item has 3 charges and regains {@dice 1d4-1} charges daily at dawn.

As an action, you can expend one charge to cast the {@spell Enlarge/Reduce|phb} spell on yourself without providing material components. You have advantage on saving throws to maintain concentration for this casting.

item.name: Bolt of Zeus
entries: Crafted by the cyclopes, this crackling, golden bolt holds the power of zeus

This item has {@dice 3d4} charges when it is found. While holding it, you can use an action to expend 1 or more of its charges to cast the {@spell lightning bolt|phb} spell (save DC 15) from it. For 1 charge, you cast the 3rd-level version of the spell. You can increase the spell slot level by one for each additional charge you expend.

If you expend the bolt's last charge roll a d20. On a 1, the bolt explodes and deals {@dice 8d6} lightning damage to all creatures within 10ft. If the roll is not a 1, the bolt crumbles into ashes and is destroyed.

item.name: Poppy of Hypnos
entries: When this poppy blooms, or takes damage, it releases a potent mist. All creatures within range are targeted by the {@spell sleep|phb} spell at 2nd level. The poppy then wilters and can not cast the spell again.

item.name: Molly
entries: This white flowering herb is known for protecting Odysseus from the witch Circe. Any creature that consumes the herb, is immune to the effects of the {@spell polymorph|phb}, {@spell true polymorph|phb} and {@spell mass polymorph|xge} spells for the next 8 hours.

language.name: Cyrik
entries: Cyrik is the most prevalent language in Cyranos, most residents will know at least some of it.
Naturally Cyrik comes in many dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Upper Cyrik
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Nobles academics and artists, especially in western regions
Upper Cyrik is a refined dialect often utilising longer and more descriptive words than those found in other dialects.

entries.name: Lower Cyrik
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Commonfolk in cities and towns, especially in north and western regions
Lower Cyrik employs a wide variety of slang terms, often with vague literal meanings, relying heavily on context and tone.

entries.name: Eastern Cyrik
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Commonfolk in cities and towns, especially in eastern regions

Eastern Cyrik is similar to Lower Cyrik, though it tends to be much shorter and blunter. Despite this, a lot can be conveyed through subtext. Arkians are especially renowned for short and blunt remarks that convey enormous subtext.

entries.name: Drakon Cyrik
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Draconic and Reptilian people, especially in Ormux and Emeris
Believed to be partly derived from Draconic, Drakon is a dialect common with draconic and reptilian peoples, being well suited to their physiology.

entries.name: Northern Cyrik
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Residents from north eastern Cyranos, especially in and around Illys
With significant migrations to and from The Northlands, Vrakos, Thalia and Trenin, Northern Cyrik borrows many terms from languages of these regions.

language.name: Gailian
entries: Gailian, also known as Ageton, is a harsh language common on Agetos Major, especially in Gailum and within the Gailum Tribes. The language originates with the Gailum Tribes, who roam around Agetos Major and occasionally meeting in Gailum, which also led to the founding of the city. The language is still heavily used by the tribes and those who frequently trade and communicate with them.

Gailian is rather tonal langauges with grunts and growls allowing for surprisingly complex communication. There are many scripts for Gaillian, with many tribes having their own unique ones, often derived from wood and stone carvings. The scripts generally have enough similarities that understanding one is enough to understand the others.
Like many languages, Gailian has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: City Tongue
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Urban residents of Gailum, especially orcs

City Tongue is a dialect of Gailian that use more closely resembles Cyrik, with fewer grunts and reliance on tone, making translations between them easier. City Tongue developed when traders began forming the permanent settlement that became the city of Gailum.

entries.name: Old Tongue
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Members of the Gailum Tribes, especially orcs
The Old Tongue is a more traditional form of the language developed by disconnected tribes occasionally crossing paths. As such, tone and context are often more important than literal meanings.

entries.name: Goblin Tongue
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Goblins across Agetos Major

The goblin tongue features fewer article words or distinction between tenses, gender or quantity. It is occasionally mocked as primitive or stupid, despite being just as nuanced as other dialects and languages.

language.name: Vrakon
entries: Vrakon is the tongue of Vrakos and the surrounding area. Much of civilisation in this area is deep underground. Both the written and spoken versions of Vrakon are well adapted to legibility in dark and dusty caverns, even with muffles and echos of such places.
Like many languages, Vrakon has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Crystal Voice
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Upper class residents of Vrakos, as well as merchants and bards

Crystal Voice is a refined and almost poetic dialect of Vrakon often spoken by nobles, merchants and performers. Combining clever wordplay and rhymes, a pleasing accent and Crystal Voice can make speakers seem more likeable and trustworthy. Using Crystal Voice properly, especially in verse, can actually be quite difficult and may require elocution lessons.

entries.name: Stone Voice
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Common residents of Vrakos, especially those from lower layers

Stone Tongue is a more common and accessable dialect of Vrakon than Crystal Voice. It features a more diverse selection a slang terms, many of which might be considered crude, vulgur or even offensive to native speakers of Crystal Voice.

language.name: Thalian
entries: Thailian is the language of the smiths and other residents of Thalia, a volcanic island in the Sea of Cyranos. While it is a unique language in its own right, its origins in Vrakon, Celestial and Primordial are noticable. The langauge notably contains lots of technical jargon and idioms based on craftwork.
Like many languages, Thalian has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Organic Thalian
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Residents of Thalia, especially dwarves and cyclopes
As the name would suggest, Organic Thalian is a dialect used most often by organic creatures of Thalia, as opposed the many constructs that originate there.

entries.name: Phaeston Thalian
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Warforged and other constructs made on Thalia

The Phaeston dialect has slighlty more in common with Celestial than other dialects. It is often used in magic charms and rituals. And is also often spoken by contructs originating from Thalia, especially those with limited personality and identity beyond their initial purpose. Phaeston features less slang, contractions and reliance on tone or sub-text than many languages.

language.name: Sign
entries: Sign language is a language that does not rely upon spoken or written word, instead using gestures to convey meanings. Sign is common among those with hearing or speech impairments, as well as between peoples who differing physiologies make sharing a spoken language difficult.
Like many languages, Sign has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Poetic Sign
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Performers and nobles

Poetic Sign is almost more a performance than a language. It contains many dance-like manoeuvres using the entire body rather than just hands and face. It may have been created by performers wanting to convey messages to audiences without worrying about language barriers.

entries.name: Western Sign
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Residents of western Cyranos
Western Sign is a simplified, and more practical version of poetic sign. Featuring far lass full body movements, relying almost entirely on head and hand movements.

entries.name: Eastern Sign
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Residents of eastern Cyranos, especially military folk

Many military folk learn at least some of this dialect in order to communicate simple messages while trying to be quiet or otherwise being drowned out by the noise of battle. However, learning more of the dialect can allow communication in wider contexts.

entries.name: Sign Language and verbal spellcasting
entries: Providing verbal components of spells using sign is very difficult, most creatures who learn sign as a second language cannot do it. However, at the DM's discretion, a creature may be able to do it, effectively replacing verbal components with somatic ones. The DM may decide that certain spells still require facial expressions, exhalations or noise, preventing gagged or silenced creatures from using them.

language.name: Elbros
entries: Elbros is a western language often considered the language of the elves, though many speak it. The language has clear influences from the languages of the Pelais Coast
Like many languages, Elbros has multiple notable dialects. Understanding one dialect is typically sufficient to understand the others.

entries.name: Higher Elbros
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Elven nobles, especially in Nyria and Halosini

Higher Elbros is sometimes considered the more refined and regal of the Elbros dialects. It bears notable ancestry from the elven languages of the Pelais Coast, as well as Upper Cyrik with long, descriptive words and less shorthand slang.

entries.name: Woodlands Elbros
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Tribal communities in the northern and western forests, especially those composed of elves and creatures of fey origin

Not unlike Higher Elbros, Woodlands Elbros bears notable ancestry from the languages of the Pelais Coast. It also shows signs of ancestry from Druidic and Sylvan, sometimes incorporating animal-like clicks and whistles to affect tone and subtext.

entries.name: Plain Elbros
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Elven commoners, especially those in cities and towns

Plain Elbros is the most common dialect of Elbros used within the cities and towns of Cyranos. With other dialects of Elbros have borrowed from local languages, especially Upper Cyrik, Plain Elbros does so to a much greater degree, and from a wider variety of dialects, particulary other variants of Cyrik. This makes Plain Elbros sound much more native to Cyrik speakers, compared to other dialects of Elbros which can sound foreign even when spoken by natives of Cyranos.

language.name: Sea Speak
entries: {@b Typical Speakers} Travellers and sailors all across Cyranos and beyond

Sea Speak is sometimes confusing mix of many languages, allowing simple communication between people all across Alvergia. Borrowing words and structures from multiple languages and dialects, it lacks consistency and can be confusing when trying to communicate anything beyond the simplest phrases.

trait.name: Brave
entries: The Amazon Huntress has advantage on saving throws against being frightened.

trait.name: Brute
entries: A weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the Amazon Huntress hits with it (included in the attack).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Amazon Huntress makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Kopis
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

trait.name: Brave
entries: The Amazon Warrior has advantage on saving throws against being frightened.

trait.name: Brute
entries: A weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the Amazon Warrior hits with it (included in the attack).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Amazon Warrior makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft. and range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage, or {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage if used with two hands to makes a melee attack.

action.name: Shield Bash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is Medium or smaller creature, it must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

action.name: Kopis
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The Amazon Warrior adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the Amazon Hoplite must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Thalian Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison and fire damage.

entries.name: Dwarven Combat Training
entries: You have proficiency with the {@item battleaxe|phb}, {@item handaxe|phb}, {@item light hammer|phb}, and {@item warhammer|phb}.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with the artisan's tools of your choice: {@item smith's tools|phb}, {@item brewer's supplies|phb}, or {@item mason's tools|phb}.

entries.name: Stonecunning
entries: Whenever you make an Intelligence ({@skill History}) check related to the origin of stonework, such as ancient columns or statues, you are considered proficient in the {@skill History} skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one other language that you and your DM agree is appropriate for your character.

entries.name: Age
entries: Thalian Cyclopes mature at the same rate as humans, but they're considered young until they reach the age of 50. On average, they live about 350 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Thalian Cyclopes tend to be neutral, prefering to dedicate to their craft rather than politics or tradition.

entries.name: Size
entries: Thalian Cyclopes are between 7 and 8 feet tall and weigh between 280 and 340 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one other language of your choice.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Thalian Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison and fire damage.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with {@item smith's tools|phb}.

entries.name: Magic Forgemaster
entries: You can cast the {@spell identify|phb} spell as a ritual. You don't require material components when you cast it using this feature.

entries.name: Poor Depth Perception
entries: You have disadvantage on any attack roll against a target more than 30 feet away.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: You count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.
Deep under the mighty volcano of Thalia generations of cyclopes have laboured for thousands of years, producing some of the greatest weapons in the known world, including the thunderbolts of Zeus.

vehicle.name: Small Ship

control.name: Helm
entries: Move up to the speed of one of its movement components, with one 90-degree turn. If the helm is destroyed, the ship can't turn.
20 ft. (requires at least 2 crew)
25 ft.; 15 ft. while sailing into the wind; 35 ft. while sailing with the wind.

weapon.name: Ballista
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 120/480 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d10}) piercing damage.

Small ships typically include a ballista only when they are equipped for combat. If a small ship is equipped with a ballista, the maximum number of passengers the ship can carry is reduced by two and the cargo capacity is reduced by 200lbs.

action: On its turn, the small ship can take 2 actions, choosing from the options below. It can take only 1 action if it has fewer than four crew. It can't take these actions if it has fewer than two crew.

items.name: Fire Ship Weapon.
items.entry: If it has at least one installed the ship can fire one of its ship weapons. Each weapon can be fired no more than once a turn. You do not need to spend actions to load or aim the weapon.

items.name: Move.
items.entry: The ship can use its helm to move with its oars or sails.

vehicle.name: Medium Ship

control.name: Helm
entries: Move up to the speed of one of its movement components, with one 90-degree turn. If the helm is destroyed, the ship can't turn.
20 ft. (requires at least 15 crew)
45 ft.; 15 ft. while sailing into the wind; 60 ft. while sailing with the wind.

weapon.name: Ballista
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 120/480 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d10}) piercing damage.

Ships typically include a ballista only when they are equipped for combat. If a ship is equipped with a ballista, the maximum number of passengers the ship can carry is reduced by two and the cargo capacity is reduced by 200 lbs.

weapon.name: Dragonsmaw
entries: Each creature in a 30-foot long 5-foot wide line must make a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The fire ignites any flammable objects in the area that arent being worn or carried.

When a Dragonsmaw is destroyed, it explodes in a ball of fire. Each creature within 10ft of the weapon must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The fire ignites any flammable objects in the area that arent being worn or carried.

Ships typically include a Dragonsmaw only when they are equipped for combat. If a ship is equipped with a dragonsmaw, the maximum number of passengers the ship can carry is reduced by two and the cargo capacity is reduced by 200 lbs.

weapon.name: Mangonels
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 200/800 ft. (can't hit targets within 60 ft. of it), one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 5d10}) bludgeoning damage.

Ships typically include a mangonels only when they are equipped for combat. If a ship is equipped with a mangonel, the maximum number of passengers the ship can carry is reduced by four and the cargo capacity is reduced by 400 lbs.

weapon.name: Naval Ram
entries: The ship has advantage on all saving throws relating to crashing when it crashes into a creature or an object. Any damage it takes from the crash is applied to the naval ram rather than to the ship. These benefits don't apply if another vessel crashes into the galley.

action: On its turn, the ship can take 3 actions, choosing from the options below. It can take only 2 actions if it has fewer than thirty crew and only 1 action if it has fewer than twenty. It can't take these actions if it has fewer than ten crew.

items.name: Fire Ship Weapon.
items.entry: If it has at least one installed the ship can fire one of its ship weapons. Each weapon can be fired no more than once a turn. You do not need to spend actions to load or aim the weapon.

items.name: Move.
items.entry: The ship can use its helm to move with its oars or sails.

20 ft. (requires at least 40 crew)

20 ft. (requires at least 40 crew)
50 ft.; 20 ft. while sailing into the wind; 70 ft. while sailing with the wind.

weapon.name: Ballista
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 120/480 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d10}) piercing damage.

Ships typically include a ballista only when they are equipped for combat. If a ship is equipped with a ballista, the maximum number of passengers the ship can carry is reduced by two and the cargo capacity is reduced by 200 lbs.

entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 200/800 ft. (can't hit targets within 60 ft. of it), one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 5d10}) bludgeoning damage.

Ships typically include a mangonels only when they are equipped for combat. If a ship is equipped with a mangonel, the maximum number of passengers the ship can carry is reduced by four and the cargo capacity is reduced by 400 lbs.

weapon.name: Naval Ram
entries: The ship has advantage on all saving throws relating to crashing when it crashes into a creature or an object. Any damage it takes from the crash is applied to the naval ram rather than to the ship. These benefits don't apply if another vessel crashes into the galley.

action: On its turn, the ship can take 4 actions, choosing from the options below. It can take only 3 actions if it has fewer than one hundred crew, only 2 action if it has fewer than eighty crew and only 1 action if it has fewer than sixty. It can't take these actions if it has fewer than forty crew.

items.name: Fire Ship Weapon.
items.entry: If it has at least one installed the ship can fire one of its ship weapons. Each weapon can be fired no more than once a turn. You do not need to spend actions to load or aim the weapon.

items.name: Move.
items.entry: The ship can use its helm to move with its oars or sails.

entries: You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this ammunition, unless it is magic ammunition that already has a bonus to those rolls.
Ammunition made of or coated with adamantine is unusually effective when used to break objects. Whenever an adamantine ammunition hits an object, the hit is a critical hit.

The adamantine version of twenty pieces of ammunition costs 750 gp more than the normal version and takes at least one workweek to make, whether the ammunition is made of the metal or coated with it. Adamantine ammunition can only be made at The Forge on Thalia.
You gain a +1 bonus to AC while you wear this armor, unless it is magic armor that already has a bonus to AC.
This suit of armor is reinforced with adamantine, one of the hardest substances in existence. While you're wearing it, any critical hit against you becomes a normal hit.

The adamantine version of a set of armor costs 750 gp more than the normal version and takes at least one workweek to make, whether the armor is made of the metal or coated with it. Adamantine armor can only be made at The Forge on Thalia.
You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this weapon, unless it is a magic weapon that already has a bonus to those rolls.
Melee weapons made of or coated with adamantine are unusually effective when used to break objects. Whenever an adamantine weapon hits an object, the hit is a critical hit.

The adamantine version of a melee weapon costs 750 gp more than the normal version and takes at least one workweek to make, whether the weapon is made of the metal or coated with it. Adamantine weapons can only be made at The Forge on Thalia.
You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.
This weapon has 3 charges and regains {@dice 1d4-1} charges daily at dawn.
When you use this weapon to kill a humanoid creature you can expend one charge to cast {@spell animate dead|phb} on that creature.
